description: Career development, interviews, and professional skills

definition.text: A strong technical resume and portfolio showcase your skills, projects, and achievements. They're your first impression and determine whether you get an interview.

keyConcepts.name: Resume Structure
keyConcepts.concept:
1. Contact Info & Links
   - Name, email, phone
   - LinkedIn, GitHub, portfolio

2. Skills Summary
   - Languages, frameworks, tools

3. Experience (most recent first)
   - Company, role, dates
   - Accomplishments with metrics

4. Projects
   - Name, tech stack, description
   - Link to demo/code

5. Education
keyConcepts.meaning: Clear structure helps recruiters scan quickly

keyConcepts.name: Writing Tips
keyConcepts.concept:
‚úì Quantify achievements
  "Reduced load time by 40%"
  "Handled 10K requests/second"

‚úì Use action verbs
  Built, Designed, Implemented

‚úì Include relevant keywords
  Match job description terms

‚úì Keep it to 1-2 pages

‚úì Proofread carefully
keyConcepts.meaning: Specific achievements are more impactful than generic descriptions

examples.question: Write a strong resume bullet point
examples.finalAnswer: Developed React dashboard with real-time analytics, reducing reporting time by 60% for 50+ stakeholders

practicalApplications.title: Job Applications
practicalApplications.description: Get past ATS and into interviews

definition.text: Your GitHub profile is often reviewed by recruiters and hiring managers. A well-maintained GitHub demonstrates your coding abilities, collaboration skills, and passion for development.

keyConcepts.name: Project READMEs
keyConcepts.concept:
Every project should have:

1. Clear title & description
2. Screenshot or demo GIF
3. Tech stack used
4. Installation instructions
5. Usage examples
6. License

Good README = Professional impression
keyConcepts.meaning: READMEs show you can communicate and document

keyConcepts.name: Profile Tips
keyConcepts.concept:
‚úì Add profile README (username/username repo)
‚úì Pin your best 6 repositories
‚úì Consistent contribution history
‚úì Quality over quantity
‚úì Include personal projects
‚úì Contribute to open source
‚úì Add profile picture and bio
keyConcepts.meaning: Curate your profile like a portfolio

examples.question: Create a project README
examples.finalAnswer: Complete README that helps users understand and use your project

definition.text: Technical interviews assess your coding abilities, problem-solving skills, and technical knowledge. Preparation and practice are key to success.

keyConcepts.name: Interview Types
keyConcepts.concept:
1. Phone Screen
   - Basic questions, culture fit

2. Coding Challenge
   - Online test, 1-2 hours
   - LeetCode-style problems

3. Technical Round
   - Live coding with interviewer
   - Problem solving, debugging

4. System Design (senior)
   - Design a scalable system

5. Behavioral
   - Past experiences, teamwork

keyConcepts.name: Problem Solving Approach
keyConcepts.concept:
1. Understand the problem
   - Ask clarifying questions
   - Identify inputs/outputs

2. Plan your approach
   - Think out loud
   - Consider edge cases

3. Code the solution
   - Start simple, then optimize

4. Test your code
   - Walk through examples
   - Check edge cases

5. Analyze complexity
   - Time and space Big O
keyConcepts.meaning: Process matters as much as the answer

examples.question: How to approach a coding interview question

steps.result: Ask: 'Can I assume the input is always valid?'
I'll use a hash map for O(n) lookup

definition.text: Behavioral interviews assess how you've handled past situations. The STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result) helps structure your responses effectively.

keyConcepts.name: STAR Method
keyConcepts.concept:
Situation: Set the context
  "In my last role, we had a tight deadline..."

Task: Describe your responsibility
  "I was responsible for..."

Action: Explain what YOU did
  "I decided to... I implemented..."

Result: Share the outcome
  "As a result, we delivered on time and..."
keyConcepts.meaning: Structured stories are more memorable and convincing

keyConcepts.name: Common Questions
keyConcepts.concept:
‚Ä¢ Tell me about a challenging project
‚Ä¢ Describe a time you disagreed with a teammate
‚Ä¢ How do you handle tight deadlines?
‚Ä¢ Tell me about a failure and what you learned
‚Ä¢ Why do you want to work here?
‚Ä¢ Where do you see yourself in 5 years?
keyConcepts.meaning: Prepare 5-6 stories that cover common themes

examples.question: Tell me about a time you solved a difficult problem

steps.result: Our API was experiencing 5-second response times during peak hours
As the senior developer, I was tasked with improving performance
I profiled the code, identified N+1 queries, and implemented caching
Response times dropped to 200ms, improving user satisfaction by 40%

examples.finalAnswer: Complete STAR response with specific actions and measurable results

practicalApplications.title: Self-reflection
practicalApplications.description: Identify your strengths and growth areas

definition.text: Technical communication is the ability to explain complex concepts clearly. It's essential for code reviews, documentation, presentations, and collaborating with non-technical stakeholders.

keyConcepts.name: Writing Good Docs
keyConcepts.concept:
‚Ä¢ Know your audience
  - Developer? User? Manager?

‚Ä¢ Structure clearly
  - Overview, details, examples

‚Ä¢ Use visuals
  - Diagrams, screenshots, code

‚Ä¢ Keep it current
  - Outdated docs are worse than none

‚Ä¢ Write like you'll forget
  - Future you is another person
keyConcepts.meaning: Good documentation saves time and prevents confusion

keyConcepts.name: Code Review Tips
keyConcepts.concept:
Giving Reviews:
‚Ä¢ Be kind and constructive
‚Ä¢ Explain the 'why'
‚Ä¢ Ask questions, don't demand
‚Ä¢ Praise good code too

Receiving Reviews:
‚Ä¢ Don't take it personally
‚Ä¢ Ask for clarification
‚Ä¢ Learn from feedback
‚Ä¢ Thank reviewers
keyConcepts.meaning: Code reviews are for learning, not criticism

examples.question: Explain a technical concept to a non-technical person

steps.result: An API is like a waiter in a restaurant
It takes your order to the kitchen and brings back your food
This is how our app gets data from the server

examples.finalAnswer: Clear explanation using analogy and connecting to context
